thread.title_full: Odd Man Out review: two David Williamsons create impressive double act

author: John Shand
title: Odd Man Out review: two David Williamsons create impressive double act
text:
Odd Man Out review: two David Williamsons create impressive double act John Shand Justin Stewart Cotta and Lisa Gormley in David Williamson's Odd Man Out Photo: Clare Hawley Fascinating to the end: Justin Stewart Cotta and Lisa Gormley. Photo: Clare Hawley 
David Williamson says he is now more psychologist than playwright. 
If such didactic preoccupations have sometimes clouded the dramaturgy of his recent work, in Odd Man Out, Williamson the psychologist and Williamson the playwright have come up with an impressive double act. Advertisement 
While the social psychologist in him shines a light on Asperger syndrome and how it affects not only people with the condition but those around them, Williamson the playwright has crafted his most compelling protagonist in years: AS-affected Ryan, grippingly portrayed by Justin Stewart Cotta. 
This is a finely-nuanced realisation of what it means to be hyper-intelligent and emotionally stunted for Ryan and the woman he marries, Alice (Lisa Gormley). Rather than interacting conventionally with the other characters, Cotta often stares into the audience with a confronting expression that simultaneously speaks of emotional vacancy or bewilderment and a brain seething with ideas. 
Having married him before she knew he was more than merely eccentric, Alice tries to coach Ryan into some vague normality of social behaviour with herself, her friends and her parents. It's a big ask. 
The only creature I've met who was as infinitely benign, kind, loving and patient as Alice was a dog. She is barely saved from being insufferably sweet by a typically Williamsonian thread of humour, by a veiled selfishness being implicit in her desire to remake Ryan, and by Gormley rising to the challenge when larger emotions are in play. 
Gael Ballantyne, Rachel Gordon, Matt Minto and Bill Young valiantly add flesh to minor characters who seem little more than sketches conveniently functioning within the plot. The upshot is that the work sags whenever Ryan is absent, but thankfully he is there for nearly all of it, and Anna Gardiner's simple set and Mark Kilmurry's direction converge with Cotta's performance in keeping our focus on his startling mind and slowly unfurling heart. 
Yes, the story becomes too predictable, but Williamson and Cotta ensure we remain fascinated by Ryan until the end. 
Until March 18.
